text.0: Watch now: NEJM Editor-in-Chief Eric Rubin, M.D., Ph.D., shares with @boston25 why he voted to approve the BNT162b2 mRNA #COVID19 vaccine. https://t.co/JNvT1cpFbw
text.1: A return to normality has increasingly come to rely on the success of vaccines to prevent #COVID19 disease and, we hope, limit further spread of infection. Would these new products be effective and safe? Today we have part of the answer, and it is strongly encouraging. #IDTwitter
text.2: An FDA advisory committee voted on Thursday that the potential benefits of the Pfizer and BioNTech #COVID19 #vaccine outweigh its risks for people ages 16 years and up.
text.3:
ICYMI: 3 local experts, from Boston based schools and hospitals, sat on the advisory committee to the FDA that recommended the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine for approval.
https://t.co/XMRAQrTAEk
text.4: A 52-year-old man with back pain was admitted with a vertebral mass, multiple lytic bone lesions, and severe hypercalcemia. MRI showed an enhancing, marrow-replacing mass involving the T1 vertebral body. On the fifth hospital day, the oxygen saturation decreased acutely.
text.5: NEJM Deputy Editor Lindsey Baden, M.D., was “part of a team that has responded to COVID-19 with an outpouring of articles; by early December, it had published some 350 items on COVID-19.” #BostoniansoftheYear https://t.co/diER2ti4HD
